title: Are there any video games based off of classical literature? - Quora

response.answer_text: A lot of them actually. Two of the Four Great Classics of Chinese literature, namely “Water Margin (Shuihuquan)” and “Romance of The Three Kingdoms (Sanguoyanyi)”, have a plethora of video games based off of them. Let’s see. Romance of The Three Kingdoms has: Romance of The Three Kingdoms. Turn-based strategy game, made by Koei. Now in its 13th installment.Dynasty Warriors. Action hack-and-slash, also made by Koei.Sango. Real-time strategy game, somewhat similar to Total Wars. Can’t remember who made this.Water Margin has: The Suikoden series. Made by Konami. Of all video games based on Water Margin, this is the most notable. Traditional JRPG with turn-based combat.Bandit Kings of Ancient China. Made by Koei. Strategy game.There are a lot more, especially for Romance of The Three Kingdoms. Just go to Wikipedia and look for them.

Spec Ops: The Line is based on Joseph Conrad's Heart of Darkness.  If you want to get more classic than that, Enslaved: Odyssey to the West is a loose adaptation of the Chinese Journey to the West, published in 1592. The entire Dynasty Warriors franchise is based off of The Romance of The Three Kingdoms, a really old series of Chinese oral histories that were finally published sometime in the 14th century. Microsoft's Age of Mythology is based on stories of Greek, Egyptian and Norse gods and goddesses, written in ancient (read: BC) times. God of War falls in the same vein.  There are many more that I haven't mentioned, but I'll stop here for now.
The best example that immediately comes to mind is Dante's Inferno which was loosely based on the first canticle (Inferno) of Dante's Divine Comedy.
Ōkami is not exactly based on literature, but on well-known Japanese mythology and lore.
